instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.
definitions.AP_RESET_L: What is AP_RESET_L? AP_RESET_L resets the wifi hardware when it is low, which will keep it from working. AP_RESET_L needs to be high for reset to not be asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
This team tells me the client that it was turned off out of nowhere.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 13.05V

CPU voltages, <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL> is 0.95 then drops to 0.66v.

There is no startup sound.

<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> present with 2.96V

<SIGNAL>AP_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.0V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> 3.31V

RAM voltages present.

I don't know what else to do, CPU dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
0.66V looks like CPU boots.
Check USB activity and external video.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: I have usb activity but I don't have external image...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Flexgate problem???

Test external video disconnecting internal LCD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: yes i did that I disconnected the flex from the LCD so that I can take an image through the USB c to HDMI adapter and nothing...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
If you get USB activity, then Caps Lock light must react too.
Is that the case?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
no, the keyboard light does not turn on, and the top case works because it is from a computer that is 100% operational.

There is no light on the keyboard but there is click on the trackpad it is very strange

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
TP click is not a life sign.
If Caps Lock doesn't react, I bet no USB activity present; be sure to check properly.
I was talking about USB activity, not USB power.
USB mouse with light on, doesn't confirm activity.

Did you try known good BIOS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: I don't understand when you mean usb activity... but when I connect a usb c to normal usb the led lights up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
